info.name: Our Lady Of Angels
info.discription: Facing the Bay of Bengal this beautiful church on Rue Dumas was built in 1852and is well worth a visit It features Greco-Roman architecture and is modelled on la Basilique Notre-Dame-du-Rosairein Lourdes in the south of France

info.name: Bodhi Beach / Serenity Beach
info.discription: A short stretch of land on the north of Puducherry’s coastal line, Bodhi Beach is ideal for calm strolls and sea gazing. This beach is a safe zone for swimming and a sea outing on the Serenity Cruise is a good choice to view the shoreline.

info.name: Chunnambar / Paradise Beach
info.discription: Chunnambar or Paradise Beach is 7 km past Puducherry along the Cuddalore main road. As the name suggests, its the Paradise on earth

info.name: The Sacred Heart Of Jesus
info.discription: At the south Boulevard stands a picturesque brown and white church, the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus. An oriental specimen of Gothic Architecture, this church’s main attraction is its stained glasses that depict events from life of Jesus Christ.

info.name: Our Lady Of The Immaculate Conception
info.discription: This Church of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception is one of the oldest tourist spots of Puducherry which has been around for close to 300 years now. Locally it is known as “Sambha Kovil” this is located in Mission street. The church is architecturally similar to churches in France.

info.name: Bharathi Park / Aayi Mandapam
info.discription: Surrounded by important heritage buildings, the Bharathi Park is a soothing oasis of greenery centrally located in the old colonial town.

info.name: Manakula Vinayagar Temple
info.discription: Not far from the Sri Aurobindo Ashram is Puducherry’s famous Ganesh temple. Predating the arrival of the French in the seventeenth century, this temple is frequented by locals and tourists alike. A major attraction of the temple is its elephant Lakshmi, who is generally outside the temple in the evenings.

info.name: Sri Aurobindo Ashram
info.discription: Every year, thousands of visitors from all over the world flock to Puducherry to visit its best-known spiritual centre, the Sri Aurobindo Ashram. The Ashram was established in 1926 by Sri Aurobindo, the great Indian freedom fighter, poet, yogi and spiritual guru.

info.name: Promenade Or Rock Beach
info.discription: Goubert Avenue runs along the coast of the Bay of Bengal and gives Pondicherry a nearly 2 km stretch of sea front. Popularly known as the Promenade Beach or the Rock Beach, it is a major tourist attraction and also a favored spot for Pondicherrians. On average it sees more than a 1000 visitors a week.

info.name: French Quarter
info.discription: One of the most striking features about Pondicherry is that it has a lot of colonial buildings which can be traced back as early as the 18th century. The speciality is that the roads are built along a grid of straight clean streets. You can find the grid pattern of roads even in other cities like Ernakulam which was done only of late.

info.name: Our Lady Of Angels
info.discription: Facing the Bay of Bengal, this beautiful church on Rue Dumas was built in 1852and is well worth a visit. It features Greco-Roman architecture, and is modelled on la Basilique Notre-Dame-du-Rosairein Lourdes, in the south of France. The exquisite stained glass windows in this church and a rare painting of Our Lady of the Assumption are its principalcharms. The latter was a gift from Napolean III.

info.name: Cercle De Pondichéry
info.discription: Le Cercle de Pondichéry on Rue Victor Simonelis a members-only recreational club which was founded in 1899 for senior French personages. Members of the Cercle can avail of its facilities, which include tennis and badminton courts. It is open to all citizens of Pondicherry, although in colonial times, it was open only to Europeans.

info.name: Public Works Department
info.discription: The Public Works Department is a heritage building on Bussy Street admired for its architectural features including high-arched French windows and an iron-wrought balcony.

info.name: Legislative Assembly
info.discription: Formerly a private residence, this heritage house was converted into the Legislative Assembly in 1962.

info.name: French Consulate
info.discription: The French Consulate is another heritage site at the corner of Rue de la Marine and Goubert Avenue. All work related with French administration takes place here.

info.name: Pondicherry Museum
info.discription: The Pondicherry Museum on Saint Louis Street boasts a collection of rare bronze and stone sculptures of the Pallava and Chola dynasties, 200 year old beads of glass and precious stones, and Greek and Roman jars which were excavated at the Arikamedu site near Pondy. Arikamedu was an ancient port that traded with the Roman Empire. The museum, which has a geology room and a shell and fossil room, also houses a collection of antique temple lamps, handicrafts, coins, church relics, French furniture, and objects from the Tsung Period in China, among other curios.

info.name: Raj Nivas (Governor’s Palace)
info.discription: Formerly inhabited by the French Governor Dupleix, the Raj Nivas is now the official residence of the Lieutenant Governor of Puducherry. Both Indian and French style architecture have been harmoniously combined in this seventeenth century heritage building. It is open to visitors only on Republic day (26th Jan), when it is also decorated with colourful fairy lights. However, the Raj Nivas is well worth viewing from outside, through its beautiful wide gates.(time?)… is a great time to visit because you can then witness the change of guards. This is an excellent place to capture memories of Pondy, so tourists, keep your cameras ready!

info.name: Statue Of Joan Of Arc
info.discription: In a garden just across the road from the Eglise de Notre Dame desAnges stands a marble statue of Joan of Arc, the well-known French heroine and Saint.

info.name: Le Café
info.discription: Le Café is now a restaurant facing the sea on the boulevard attracting tourists and local people alike. Earlier this was a port office when railway ran from the South boulevard to the old iron pier. Baguettes, croissants, salads, cake and organic South Indian coffee are some of the major food items you should go for when visiting this restaurant. The sea side breeze and the sea view makes it an interesting attraction on the beach.

info.name: Old Distillery
info.discription: The old Distillery is located just where the boulevard begins. Tucked into a corner this run down structure was used as a parking lot for many years before PondyART, a Puducherry based organisation leased it for being used as exhibition spaces. Since 2013 a number of Photo exhibitions have been organised in this place including a 10-day photo festival in March 2014.

info.name: Douane (Customs Office)
info.discription: The Douane Customs Building was built during the French rule and till today holds memories of the colonial reign. It’s a typical French colonial architecture, now with an Indian flag atop. The architecture with the national emblem fuses two different cultures bridging the past with present.

info.name: Dupleix Statue
info.discription: On the beach road, also known as Goubert Avenue is a stylish French building facing the sea. This building reminds you of sea resorts in France. Presently it is used as the Municipality office of Puducherry.

info.name: La Mairie (Municipality)
info.discription: In recognition of the services of Marquis Joseph Francois Dupleix, who was the Governor of Puducherry between 1742 and 1754 two statues of him were commissioned to be built by the French Government. One of the statues were installed at the southern end of the rock beach. Dupleix was an important figure in the colonial past of Puducherry and was instrumental in preventing British dominance in Puducherry. The 2.88 meter tall statue was built in the year 1870.

info.name: French War Memorial
info.discription: Also on the Beach Road is a French war Memorial in honour of the French soldiers who lost their lives in World War I. The memorial has four tall pillars, two on each side, and a soldier leaning on a rifle in the middle. On the memorial there is an inscription that says, “Aux combattants des Indes Françaises morts pour la patrie, 1914-1918” which means French fighters of India who died for their country in 1914-1918. On Bastille day, July 14th every year the memorial is lit up beautifully and homage is paid to the soldiers.

info.name: Old Lighthouse
info.discription: Situated on the edge of the sea is the old lighthouse that was built in 1836. The lighthouse was considered to be quite modern for that time with its unique circular structure and square base. The beacon was imported from France and this was the first lighthouse in Puducherry. Before this lighthouse was built there was no other signal for ships coming into Puducherry. The 29 metres tall lighthouse was shut down in the year 1979, but is an interesting place to visit.

info.name: Gandhi Statue
info.discription: Standing majestically in the Boulevard of the Rock Beach is the 4 meter tall statue of Mahatma Gandhi facing the statue of Jawahar lal Nehru. The statue is surrounded by eight exquisitely carved monolithic granite pillars of the 17th century that were supposedly brought from Gingee. The statue along with the dome, which is twice as large as the statue itself, was built by sculptor Roy Choudhary.

info.name: Manakula Vinayagar Temple
info.discription: Not far from the Sri Aurobindo Ashram is Puducherry’s famous Ganesh temple. Predating the arrival of the French in the seventeenth century, this temple is frequented by locals and tourists alike. A major attraction of the temple is its elephant Lakshmi, who is generally outside the temple in the evenings. Make sure you have a few coins or a note ready for her, and she will gently bless you on the head with her trunk.

info.name: Sri Aurobindo Ashram
info.discription: Every year, thousands of visitors from all over the world flock to Puducherry to visit its best-known spiritual centre, the Sri Aurobindo Ashram. The Ashram was established in 1926 by Sri Aurobindo, the great Indian freedom fighter, poet, yogi and spiritual guru. The Mother was Sri Aurobindo’s spiritual collaborator, and when he subsequently decided to withdraw from his outer life to focus on his spiritual work, she took over the running of the Ashram.Located on Rue de la Marine, the main Ashram building is an old French house where the Mother and Sri Aurobindo lived. Today, the Ashram courtyard houses their Samadhi. The Samadhi can be visited all year round but the rooms are open to visitors only on Darshan days.

info.name: Promenade Or Rock Beach
info.discription: Goubert Avenue runs along the coast of the Bay of Bengal and gives Pondicherry a nearly 2 km stretch of sea front. Popularly known as the Promenade Beach or the Rock Beach, it is a major tourist attraction and also a favored spot for Pondicherrians. On average it sees more than a 1000 visitors a week.Most mornings are filled with health conscious people having a brisk walk, exercising and jogging along the sea shore. In the evenings the road is closed to traffic and one can find street vendors selling balloons, handicrafts, toys and all sort of trinkets mingling with the crowds on the road and pavement. Carts offering street food are parked on the sand.The beach road also features some of the important landmarks of Pondicherry. The statue of Mahatma Gandhi takes center stage, it is located at the spot that was the entrance to what used to be the erstwhile pier of Puducherry. It is surrounded by 8 imposing tall stone pillars, each intricately carved from a single piece of rock. Across from the statue is the fair ground on which cultural festivals and other public events are hosted.Other landmarks to be seen are the Old Light House, the Customs House, The Kargil War Memorial, The Hôtel de Ville (which is the French equivalent for Town Hall) and at the far end the statue of Dupleix can be found in a small park.

info.name: Public Works Department
info.discription: The Public Works Department is a heritage building on Bussy Street admired for its architectural features including high-arched French windows and an iron-wrought balcony.

info.name: Legislative Assembly
info.discription: Formerly a private residence, this heritage house was converted into the Legislative Assembly in 1962.

info.name: Le Foyer Du Soldat
info.discription: Le Foyer du Soldat is not far from the Pondy beach road. It is an old colonial building situated on Rue Law de Lauriston, serving as a legion hall for local retired soldiers who fought for France in a number of wars abroad.

info.name: Lycée Français
info.discription: The Lycée Français on Rue Victor Simonel is a French school which was set up in 1826 and continues to provide a French education to its students. It is a beautiful colonial building and houses a rare collection of coins of the French East India Company as well as old photographs of colonial Pondicherry.

info.name: Saint Joseph De Cluny
info.discription: Known for the lovely embroidery produced in its work shop, Saint Joseph de Cluny on Romain Rolland Street is another heritage site which was donated to the order of Saint Joseph of Cluny around 150 years ago.

info.name: French Institute Of Pondicherry
info.discription: Inaugurated in 1955, the internationally renowned French Institute of Pondicherry is a thriving centre of research primarily in the fields of Indology, social sciences and ecology. It has an extensive and steadily expanding research library which houses a wealth of old palm-leaf and paper manuscripts in Sanskrit and Tamil, including a UNESCO “Memory of the World” collection of Shaiva manuscripts.

info.name: French Consulate
info.discription: The French Consulate is another heritage site at the corner of Rue de la Marine and Goubert Avenue. All work related with French administration takes place here.Every year on the 14th of July which is the French National Day, the Consulate hosts celebrations, the highlight of which are the splendid fireworks on the beach promenade.

info.name: Alliance Française
info.discription: The Alliance Française de Pondichéry on Rue Suffren is housed in another heritage building and is probably the most popular French language institution in town. It also has a cultural and information centre, a library, and an auditorium which are accessible to all of its members and students. The primary aim of the Alliance is to promote the French language and culture, and to encourage cultural interactions between France and India. There are regular stage performances and exhibitions organized by the Alliance, and these are usually held either in its auditorium or in Maison Colombani.

info.name: Raj Nivas (Governor’s Palace)
info.discription: Formerly inhabited by the French Governor Dupleix, the Raj Nivas is now the official residence of the Lieutenant Governor of Puducherry. Both Indian and French style architecture have been harmoniously combined in this seventeenth century heritage building. It is open to visitors only on Republic day (26th Jan), when it is also decorated with colourful fairy lights. However, the Raj Nivas is well worth viewing from outside, through its beautiful wide gates.(time?)… is a great time to visit because you can then witness the change of guards. This is an excellent place to capture memories of Pondy, so tourists, keep your cameras ready!

info.name: Manakula Vinayagar Temple
info.discription: Not far from the Sri Aurobindo Ashram is Puducherry’s famous Ganesh temple. Predating the arrival of the French in the seventeenth century, this temple is frequented by locals and tourists alike. A major attraction of the temple is its elephant Lakshmi, who is generally outside the temple in the evenings. Make sure you have a few coins or a note ready for her, and she will gently bless you on the head with her trunk.

info.name: Sri Aurobindo Ashram
info.discription: Every year, thousands of visitors from all over the world flock to Puducherry to visit its best-known spiritual centre, the Sri Aurobindo Ashram. The Ashram was established in 1926 by Sri Aurobindo, the great Indian freedom fighter, poet, yogi and spiritual guru. The Mother was Sri Aurobindo’s spiritual collaborator, and when he subsequently decided to withdraw from his outer life to focus on his spiritual work, she took over the running of the Ashram.Located on Rue de la Marine, the main Ashram building is an old French house where the Mother and Sri Aurobindo lived. Today, the Ashram courtyard houses their Samadhi. The Samadhi can be visited all year round but the rooms are open to visitors only on Darshan days.

info.name: Statue Of Joan Of Arc
info.discription: In a garden just across the road from the Eglise de Notre Dame desAnges stands a marble statue of Joan of Arc, the well-known French heroine and Saint.

info.name: Children’s Park
info.discription: In a garden just across the road from the Eglise de Notre Dame desAnges stands a marble statue of Joan of Arc, the well-known French heroine and Saint.

info.name: Le Café
info.discription: Le Café is now a restaurant facing the sea on the boulevard attracting tourists and local people alike. Earlier this was a port office when railway ran from the South boulevard to the old iron pier. Baguettes, croissants, salads, cake and organic South Indian coffee are some of the major food items you should go for when visiting this restaurant. The sea side breeze and the sea view makes it an interesting attraction on the beach.

info.name: Kargil War Memorial
info.discription: The Kargil was memorial was built in remembrance of the Kargil war which claimed the lives of over 500 Indian soldiers. The memorial is a small structure n sober grey stone with four pillars on the side.

info.name: Old Distillery
info.discription: The old Distillery is located just where the boulevard begins. Tucked into a corner this run down structure was used as a parking lot for many years before PondyART, a Puducherry based organisation leased it for being used as exhibition spaces. Since 2013 a number of Photo exhibitions have been organised in this place including a 10-day photo festival in March 2014.

info.name: Douane (Customs Office)
info.discription: The Douane Customs Building was built during the French rule and till today holds memories of the colonial reign. It’s a typical French colonial architecture, now with an Indian flag atop. The architecture with the national emblem fuses two different cultures bridging the past with present.

info.name: La Mairie (Municipality)
info.discription: On the beach road, also known as Goubert Avenue is a stylish French building facing the sea. This building reminds you of sea resorts in France. Presently it is used as the Municipality office of Puducherry.

info.name: French War Memorial
info.discription: Also on the Beach Road is a French war Memorial in honour of the French soldiers who lost their lives in World War I. The memorial has four tall pillars, two on each side, and a soldier leaning on a rifle in the middle. On the memorial there is an inscription that says, “Aux combattants des Indes Françaises morts pour la patrie, 1914-1918” which means French fighters of India who died for their country in 1914-1918. On Bastille day, July 14th every year the memorial is lit up beautifully and homage is paid to the soldiers.

info.name: French War Memorial
info.discription: Situated on the edge of the sea is the old lighthouse that was built in 1836. The lighthouse was considered to be quite modern for that time with its unique circular structure and square base. The beacon was imported from France and this was the first lighthouse in Puducherry. Before this lighthouse was built there was no other signal for ships coming into Puducherry. The 29 metres tall lighthouse was shut down in the year 1979, but is an interesting place to visit.

info.name: French War Memorial
info.discription: Standing majestically in the Boulevard of the Rock Beach is the 4 meter tall statue of Mahatma Gandhi facing the statue of Jawahar lal Nehru. The statue is surrounded by eight exquisitely carved monolithic granite pillars of the 17th century that were supposedly brought from Gingee. The statue along with the dome, which is twice as large as the statue itself, was built by sculptor Roy Choudhary.

info.name: Promenade Or Rock Beach
info.discription: Goubert Avenue runs along the coast of the Bay of Bengal and gives Pondicherry a nearly 2 km stretch of sea front. Popularly known as the Promenade Beach or the Rock Beach, it is a major tourist attraction and also a favored spot for Pondicherrians. On average it sees more than a 1000 visitors a week.Most mornings are filled with health conscious people having a brisk walk, exercising and jogging along the sea shore. In the evenings the road is closed to traffic and one can find street vendors selling balloons, handicrafts, toys and all sort of trinkets mingling with the crowds on the road and pavement. Carts offering street food are parked on the sand.The beach road also features some of the important landmarks of Pondicherry. The statue of Mahatma Gandhi takes center stage, it is located at the spot that was the entrance to what used to be the erstwhile pier of Puducherry. It is surrounded by 8 imposing tall stone pillars, each intricately carved from a single piece of rock. Across from the statue is the fair ground on which cultural festivals and other public events are hosted.Other landmarks to be seen are the Old Light House, the Customs House, The Kargil War Memorial, The Hôtel de Ville (which is the French equivalent for Town Hall) and at the far end the statue of Dupleix can be found in a small park.

info.name: French War Memorial
info.discription: Standing majestically in the Boulevard of the Rock Beach is the 4 meter tall statue of Mahatma Gandhi facing the statue of Jawahar lal Nehru. The statue is surrounded by eight exquisitely carved monolithic granite pillars of the 17th century that were supposedly brought from Gingee. The statue along with the dome, which is twice as large as the statue itself, was built by sculptor Roy Choudhary.

info.name: Our Lady Of Angels
info.discription: Facing the Bay of Bengal, this beautiful church on Rue Dumas was built in 1852and is well worth a visit. It features Greco-Roman architecture, and is modelled on la Basilique Notre-Dame-du-Rosairein Lourdes, in the south of France. The exquisite stained glass windows in this church and a rare painting of Our Lady of the Assumption are its principalcharms. The latter was a gift from Napolean III.This is the only Church in Pondy which celebrates mass in English, French and Tamil.

info.name: Saint Anthony’s Shrine
info.addr: Lal Bahadur Sastri Road, Ambedkar Nagar
info.discription: One of the many quaint shrines in Puducherry, Saint Anthony’s Shrine on Suffren Street is worth a visit.

info.name: Church Of The Capuchins
info.discription: Situated on Rue Dumas, the Church of the Capuchins was one of the earliest churches of Pondicherry, and one of the few buildings that somewhat survived the destruction that occurred during the Third Carnatic War in 1761. It has since been renovated and is now used as an orphanage.

info.name: Our Lady Of Lourdes
info.discription: Our Lady of Lourdes is a Marian Shrine located in Villianur town. This Roman Catholic church, devoted to Mother Mary was built in 1863 and attracts many pilgrims. The miraculous Statue of Our Lady of Lourdes was brought from Lourdes and was the workmanship of the same sculptor who sculpted the statue of Our Lady of Lourdes, Lourdes Grotto, France.

info.name: The Sacred Heart Of Jesus
info.discription: At the south Boulevard stands a picturesque brown and white church, the Church of the Sacred Heart of Jesus. An oriental specimen of Gothic Architecture, this church’s main attraction is its stained glasses that depict events from life of Jesus Christ. This 18th century church is quite close to the Railway station of Puducherry. The year 2008-09 was celebrated as the centenary year of founding of the parish and a special postal stamp and postal envelope were released to mark the occasion.

info.name: Our Lady Of The Immaculate Conception
info.discription: This Church of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception is one of the oldest tourist spots of Puducherry which has been around for close to 300 years now. Locally it is known as “Sambha Kovil” this is located in Mission street. The church is architecturally similar to churches in France. The Immaculate Conception of Blessed Virgin Mary, which is the fest of this church is celebrated with great pomp and fair on 8th December. Mass services are held in both English and Tamil. Historically, at this site there were three churches that were built before this church but was demolished during various wars. This is (fourth church) the cathedral mother church for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Puducherry and Cuddalore.

info.name: Kanniga Parameswari Temple
info.discription: Shakthi, the supreme feminine divine force has a temple dedicated to her on the MG Road, the Kanniga Parameswari temple. This architectural marvel is a blend of both French and traditional Tamil style of architecture. The Ionic columns, arched walls and stained windows reminds you of a French building, while the granite pillars and Sanctum sanctoram are of typical Tamil designs. Every year during the Tamil month of Aadi (July-Aug), the temple has many special poojas and rituals to which thousands of devotees come and seek the blessings of the goddess.

info.name: Vedhapureeswarar Temple
info.discription: Also on the MG road, the Vedhapureeswarar temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva. As with other South Indian temples, this temple also has a Rajagopuram which is 70 feet tall and featuring statues of gods and goddesses. The shrine of Lord Muruga housed in this temple was praised by Sri Ramalinga Swamigal in his hymns. It also has a separate shrine dedicated to Lord Dakshinamoorthy. According to history, this temple which is now more than 500 years old, was destroyed in the year 1748 and was reconstructed in the year 1788 with the painstaking efforts of Dewan Kandappa Mudaliar and the local people.

info.name: Varadharaja Perumal Kovil
info.discription: Holding the honour of one of the oldest temples of this town, the Varadharaja Perumal temple is located in MG road and is dedicated to Lord Vishnu. Built in a typical Dravidian style of architecture it has a colourful Gopuram and pillars adorned with sculptures of various deities. This temple dates back to 600 AD and according to local legends, it was meant to be dedicated to Rama, Sita, Lakshmana and Hanuman. The temple also houses an idol of Narasimha, the fourth incarnation Lord Vishnu. Annaprasanam, or first rice feeding to infants is a speciality of this temple.

info.name: Manakula Vinayagar Temple
info.discription: Not far from the Sri Aurobindo Ashram is Puducherry’s famous Ganesh temple. Predating the arrival of the French in the seventeenth century, this temple is frequented by locals and tourists alike. A major attraction of the temple is its elephant Lakshmi, who is generally outside the temple in the evenings. Make sure you have a few coins or a note ready for her, and she will gently bless you on the head with her trunk.

info.name: Meeran Mosque
info.discription: Built almost 350 years ago, Meeran mosque is one of the oldest mosques of Puducherry. It was built by Arcot Navab in the old Gothic Islam style of architecture. The mosque has four grand pillars  below its dome with Meerhath near it and Meember next to it. The mosque is frequented by many devout Muslims as everyday prayer sessions are held.

info.name: Mulla Mohamed Mosque
info.discription: A part of Kuthbha mosque was built as Mulla Mohamed mosque, to preach Urdu. With a small pond of fishes, a clean hall used for cooking during Ramzan this mosque also has Jenesha. During all the important festivals, the mosque is brightly lit and beautifully decorated.

info.name: Kuthbha Mosque
info.discription: Kuthbha literally means preaching. This mosque is the first mosque of Puducherry, which was built in the white town area. It is said that during the 17th century, the then French government ordered the relocation of this mosque to the Muslim quarters, in the South West side of the canal. The mosque houses the dargaa of Moulla Saiubum and has daily preachings and special prayers on Fridays.

info.name: Veerampattinam Beach
info.discription: Veerampattinam beach is one of the most beautiful beaches of the country attracting thousands of tourist from all over the world. It is the biggest coastal village of Puducherry located between Puducherry and Cuddalore and 7 km away from Puducherry. The village is surrounded by rivers on both sides with dedicated fishing sites. The fishermen here work with traditional fishing crafts and nets which adds to the ambience. Veerampattinam is famous for two things, one is the Car festival for which thousands throng the place every year during the Tamil month of Aadi (July – August) and the other is Maasi Magam, during the Tamil month of Maasi (February – March). The Sri Sengazhuneer Amman Temple of Veerampattinam is an immensely popular temple among the locals.

info.name: Auroville Beach
info.discription: Auroville or Auro beach is about 12 km from Puducherry along the ECR. The beach is right opposite to the road that leads to Auroville from ECR. Its a hotspot for Aurovillians and tourists alike. Weekends on this beach tend to get fairly crowded with people from nearby towns coming in for a relaxation. With the fishermen community closely located, sea food is quite popular here.

info.name: Bodhi Beach / Serenity Beach
info.discription: A short stretch of land on the north of Puducherry’s coastal line, Bodhi Beach is ideal for calm strolls and sea gazing. This beach is a safe zone for swimming and a sea outing on the Serenity Cruise is a good choice to view the shoreline. As the beach is surrounded by fishermen village, its a good place to buy fresh catch of the day. Also this is the only beach where surfing is taught.

info.name: Bodhi Beach / Serenity Beach
info.discription: Chunnambar or Paradise Beach is 7 km past Puducherry along the Cuddalore main road. As the name suggests, its the Paradise on earth. The beach is accessible through boats from the Boathouse of Chunnambar which is located at Ariyankuppam. A 15-20 minute ride takes you to the clean and serene Paradise beach, a small stretch of island with blue sea and sky all around. The beach is the point where Chunnambar river mingles with the backwaters of Bay of Bengal. The sea is not very aggressive here and hence is ideal for swimming and safe for children. There are separate tickets for entering into the boat house and for boat rides. The ride to the beach takes a route surrounded by dense forests with hints of palm groves here and there. The sparsely populated beach is the perfect weekend getaway from your bustling busy city lives.

info.name: Promenade Or Rock Beach
info.discription: Goubert Avenue runs along the coast of the Bay of Bengal and gives Pondicherry a nearly 2 km stretch of sea front. Popularly known as the Promenade Beach or the Rock Beach, it is a major tourist attraction and also a favored spot for Pondicherrians. On average it sees more than a 1000 visitors a week.Most mornings are filled with health conscious people having a brisk walk, exercising and jogging along the sea shore. In the evenings the road is closed to traffic and one can find street vendors selling balloons, handicrafts, toys and all sort of trinkets mingling with the crowds on the road and pavement. Carts offering street food are parked on the sand.The beach road also features some of the important landmarks of Pondicherry. The statue of Mahatma Gandhi takes center stage, it is located at the spot that was the entrance to what used to be the erstwhile pier of Puducherry. It is surrounded by 8 imposing tall stone pillars, each intricately carved from a single piece of rock. Across from the statue is the fair ground on which cultural festivals and other public events are hosted.Other landmarks to be seen are the Old Light House, the Customs House, The Kargil War Memorial, The Hôtel de Ville (which is the French equivalent for Town Hall) and at the far end the statue of Dupleix can be found in a small park.

info.name: Botanical Garden
info.discription: Built in the ornate French style with pruned trees, flower beds, gravel paths and fountains, the Botanical Garden was laid down in the year 1826 in the middle of old Tamil town. Perroret transformed this into a botanical garden by bringing in many exotic plant species from all over the world with the help of the French people. There is said to be nearly 1500 rare plant species here. The garden houses an aquarium and a joy train that tours around the garden. There is also a musical fountain that is functional on all weekends.

info.name: Arikamedu
info.discription: Arikamedu, now a part of Ariyankuppam has a long history which dates back to the 2nd century BC. This port, according to archaeological findings were inhabited by Romans, Cholas and the French. The remains of 18th century which were discovered also suggests that pottery, dyed textiles and semi-precious stones were materials that were popular for trading here.

info.name: Bharathi Park / Aayi Mandapam
info.discription: Surrounded by important heritage buildings, the Bharathi Park is a soothing oasis of greenery centrally located in the old colonial town.At the heart of the park is the Aayi Mandapam. Built in the Greco-Roman style during the reign of Napoleon III, it is a well-known landmark of Puducherry, and many regard it as the official symbol of the union territory. This monument commemorates the provision of water to the colonial city during Napoleon’s reign, and is named after a courtesan called ‘Aayi’ who is said to have demolished her home to build a reservoir for the town’s water supply.There is also a children’s playground in the park.

info.name: Pondicherry Museum
info.discription: The Pondicherry Museum on Saint Louis Street boasts a collection of rare bronze and stone sculptures of the Pallava and Chola dynasties, 200 year old beads of glass and precious stones, and Greek and Roman jars which were excavated at the Arikamedu site near Pondy. Arikamedu was an ancient port that traded with the Roman Empire. The museum, which has a geology room and a shell and fossil room, also houses a collection of antique temple lamps, handicrafts, coins, church relics, French furniture, and objects from the Tsung Period in China, among other curios.

info.name: Bharathidasan Museum
info.discription: Bharathidasan was a Tamil poet and playwright, born in Puducherry in 1891. Bharathidasan means disciple of Bharathi. He has also written scripts for films on themes of Dravidian culture and women empowerments. His house in Perumal Kovil street was later converted into a museum, preserving his artefacts along with his literary works.

info.name: Bharathi Memorial Museum
info.discription: Subramaniya Bharathi, a renowned Tamil poet and patriot, came to Puducherry in 1908 as a fugitive from Britishers. The calming and serene atmosphere of Puducherry enabled this revolutionary poet to compose some of his best songs. The house that he lived in, located at Eswaran Dharmaraja Kovil street was later transformed into a museum in his memory. The Bharathi memorial museum was recently renovated and now serves as a revered place for all.

info.name: Rangapillai Museum
info.discription: Rangapillai museum was once the mansion of Ananda Ranga Pillai, dubash of Dupleix, built around 1738. Pillai’s journals and diaries written when French rule flourished in Puducherry serve as a great source of historical information about a bygone era. Like many buildings of Puducherry, this mansion is also built as a fusion of French and Indian style of architecture. Even though the building has lost its former sheen and glory, as one of the oldest surviving buildings of Puducherry, it is of monumental importance to the history of the town. Special permission is required to visit the mansion.

info.name: Auroville
info.discription: Auroville (City of Dawn) is an experimental township in Viluppuram district in the state of Tamil Nadu, India, near Puducherry in South India. It was founded in 1968 by Mirra Alfassa (also known as “The Mother”) and designed by architect Roger Anger. As stated in Alfassa’s first public message about the township, Auroville is meant to be a universal town where men and women of all countries are able to live in peace and progressive harmony, above all creeds, all politics and all nationalities. The purpose of Auroville is to realize human unity.

info.name: Other Places In Auroville
info.discription: Cultural: Bharat Nivas, Unity Pavilion, Tibetan Pavilion, Sadhana Forest, Buddha Garden, CSR and Upasana. Restaurants: Tanto, Frites Corner (formerly New Creation Corner), Roma’s Kitchen, Visitor Centre Cafe, Well Cafe, Ganesh Bakery, Farm Fresh and Auroville Bakery

info.name: Visitors Centre – Auroville
info.discription: The Visitors Centre offers all the vital information about Auroville. The centre is open from 9 in the morning to 5.30 in the evening. There is a permanent exhibition on the history and philosophy of Auroville and an information service that offers books, brochures and leaflets on the various aspects of Auroville. Apart from these, there are also shopping centres for garments, jewellery, handicrafts etc. all designed from natural fabric and fibres by designers from Auroville.The pass to visit Matrimandir can be obtained from the Visitors Centre.

info.name: Matrimandir – Auroville
info.discription: Matrimandir is the central attraction of Auroville and represents the Universal Mother or the Divine Consciousness. This is the most sacred place for the Aurovillians. It is built like a golden globe with four massive pillars for support. It took a total of 38 years to build this beautiful and divine building. There are 12 rooms inside the Matrimandir which represent the 12 virtues of the Mother. The 12 gardens around the amphitheatre represent the 12 powers of the Universal Mother. The outer layer of the globe is gold plated, with ta giant crystal at the top through which sunlight falls inside. Entry into the Matrimandir is restricted. Prior passes are to be obtained from the Visitors Centre to gain entry.

info.name: Auroville Botanical Garden
info.discription: The Auroville Botanical Garden was set up with an aim to deal with the disappearing Tropical Dry Evergreen Forest of South India. The decrease in forest covers poses a great threat and calls for conservation of genetic diversity in the plant kingdom in different climatic conditions. More than 250 tree species have been planted and preserved here. This project, undertaken by Auroville also offers various educational programme to create awareness among school children.

info.name: Maha Kaleswarar Temple
info.discription: The Maha Kaleswarar temple is an ancient temple of Lord Shiva more than 1000 years old, situated at Irumbai near Auroville. This place also features in verses of Thiru Gnana Sambanthar, one of the famed poets and Devotees of the famous four. Hence it is called ‘Paadal pettra sthalam’ meaning the holy place mentioned in holy verses. This temple has facets of copper dedicated to the Hindu Trinity gods of Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva.

info.name: Natarajar Temple (Pyramid)
info.discription: Sri Karaneswara Nataraja temple, dedicated to Lord Shiva is located near Pudhukuppam, around 18 km away from Puducherry, along the ECR. The temple mirrors the structure of The Great Pyramids of Egypt, but also follows the traditional principles of Indian style of building temples. It has three paths for pradhakshina and the entrance faces the south, as Lord Shiva is also known as Dakshinamurthy, the Teacher of South. The temple was designed and constructed by the legendary Dr. Karan Singh, the last Maharaja of Kashmir as part of his family traditions.

info.name: Panchavati Hanuman Temple
info.discription: This turn of the century is temple, dedicated to Lord Hanuman, a devotee of Lord Rama, is one of its kind. The Hanuman idol is one of 36 ft tall and is considered to be one of the tallest idols. Located in the old Pondy-Tindivanam road, at about 7 km from Puducherry, this temple was consecrated on 31st January, 2007. Since then, it is serving as an important pilgrim site attracting people form all over Tamilnadu and India. Apart from Hanuman, the temple also has shrines dedicated to Lord Ganesha, Lord Rama with Sita and Lakshman too.

info.name: Ousteri Lake
info.discription: Ousteri lake is the most important fresh water lake of Puducherry, situated towards north of the town some 10 km away (on the Puducherry-Villupuram road). Te lake was a primary source of drinking water for Puducherry town earlier. Now, it is basically a bird sanctuary and an internationally recognized wetland. The place sees many migratory birds during the migratory season starting in late August. There is a wide range of aquatic species too. There is a small children’s park which serves as a nice picnic spot. Boating facilities are also available.

info.name: Thirukameswar Temple
info.discription: This historical Thirukameswar and Kokilambigai Temple is a temple devoted to Lord Shiva is located at the heart of the Villianur town of Puducherry. Every year it hosts a car festival for 10 days for which people come from far and wide for a blessed darshan of the lord.

info.name: Arikamedu
info.discription: Arikamedu, now a part of Ariyankuppam has a long history which dates back to the 2nd century BC. This port, according to archaeological findings were inhabited by Romans, Cholas and the French. The remains of 18th century which were discovered also suggests that pottery, dyed textiles and semi-precious stones were materials that were popular for trading here.

info.name: Sri Aurobindo Handmade Paper
info.addr: No. 50, S.V. Patel Salai & Kasim Salai

info.name: Renaissance Antiques
info.addr: No.2, Near Ayyanar Temple, Auroville Turn, E Coast Rd

info.name: Tiruvannamalai – 110km
info.discription: The place derives its name from the deity of the Annamalaiyar Temple. This temple is spread out on 25 acres and is one of the largest temples in India. On a full moon night between November and December, the Karthigai Deepam festival is celebrated by having a huge light lit at the top of the Annamalai hill which attracts thousands of pilgrims. The place is also popular for Jains, as it has a sculpture of Neminatha, which is the tallest Jain image in Tamil nadu. The Ramana Ashram and Yogi Ramsuratkumar situated around the hill are also popular tourist attractions.

info.name: Tranquebar – 117km
info.discription: The once active trading centre for the Danish is now a quiet place. The Zion Church in Tharangambadi is the oldest Protestant church in India which was sanctified in 1701. A visit to the museum and the fort is an experience in itself. Also the quiet shore adds to the tranquil ambience. A day spent exploring the fort and museum and finally relaxing along the shore is as good as it can get.

info.name: Pitchavaram – 67km
info.discription: It is one of the world’s largest mangrove forest spread out over 1100 Hectares consisting of numerous islands. The Pitchavaram mangroves attract a lot of local as well as migrant birds, the migratory season for birds here is between September and April. In February, one can participate in the” Dawn Fest” or ‘Vidiyal Vizha’, organised by the tourism department of Tamil Nadu. It is also a good picnic spot and you can entertain yourself in water sports like kayaking, rowing and canoeing.

info.name: Kancheepuram – 130km
info.discription: Kanchipuram has several historical and mythological stories attached to it. The city is one of the most famous holy pilgrimage places for both Saivites and Vaishnavites. Jain temple, Shankaracharya Math, and silk saris are added attractions to this place.

info.name: Gangaikonda Cholapuram – 99km
info.discription: This town was constructed in the 11th century during the Chola period, as a capital city of the Kingdom, by Rajendra Chola I. The stone crafted Shiva temple with incredible sculptures and intricate carvings is an architectural and engineering marvel. The Shiva lingam that you find here is next only to the Brihadeeswara temple of Tanjore in its size. The most unique feature of this temple is that the shadow of the main tower never falls on the ground throughout the year.

info.name: Dakshinachitram – 125km
info.discription: A one stop place to experience South Indian traditional architecture. You can find contemporary art and culture along with traditional ones of South India here. Frequent live folk performances are organised in the amphitheatre of Dakshinachitram. It has about 17 heritage houses that depict lifestyles of different part of South India. Artworks of both well established and emerging artists are often put up as contextual exhibitions.

info.name: Chidambaram – 74km
info.discription: Chidambaram, which is about 70 km from Puducherry, is famous for Vaitheeswaran temple. It is a renowned pilgrimage for the devotees of Shiva, one of the trinity Hindu gods. Mythologically, Chidambaram is also the holy place associated with space or akash, one of the five elements(pancha maha bhutas) of nature. Its history as well as its architecture attracts thousands of visitors every day. Sculptures depicting Natya Karnas (artistic postures) of Bhartanatyam, the traditional dance of Tamil Nadu adorn the gateway. This huge temple with four archways or gopurams facing the four directions is the built in the centre of the city. Chidambaram is also famous for its annual cultural fest called Natyanajali where renowned performers of Bharatanatyam perform before the King of dancing, Lord Shiva at the Vaitheeswaran temple.

info.name: Mahabalipuram – 98km
info.discription: Mamallapuram, the 1st Christian Era township, also known as Mahabalipuram, is a UNESCO World Heritage site and it is situated along the shores of Bay of Bengal. The city was built during the reign of Narasimha Pallava who had a great interest in all forms of classical art including sculpting. There are various stone sculptures and carved temples dedicated to various Hindu deities and the five Pandavas.

info.name: Mahabalipuram – 98km
info.discription: Famous for its fort, Gingee has become a popular tourist destination. The stone pillars and statues in the Bharathi Park and Gandhi Thidal on the Beach Road were brought by the French in Pondy from Gingee. The place is also popular due to the various temples here and its history. Gingee is located between three hills.
